body:
/kind bug

**What happened**:
When running Kubernetes against an installation of DevStack which deploys the Cinder service at a path rather than a port (ex: http://foo.bar/volume rather than http://foo.bar:xxx), the version detection fails.

**What you expected to happen**:
The version detection should never happen.  The best way to detect version is by using the OpenStack service catalog.  As per the [service types authority](http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/service-types-authority/), the services will be labeled `cinder` for V1, `cinderv2` for V2 and `cinderv3` for V3.  This is the correct way of detecting the right Cinder version.

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:
Install DevStack and attempt to launch a volume with Kubernetes integrated to that cloud (or any cloud that runs Cinder in a path.

**Anything else we need to know?**:
There should never be a case where `cinder`, `cinderv2` and `cinderv3` don't give the right information as all major documentation (and installation tools) point to doing this:

- [Manual Installation](https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/install/cinder-controller-install-rdo.html)
- [Puppet, TripleO](https://github.com/openstack/puppet-cinder/blob/master/manifests/keystone/auth.pp)
- [OpenStack Ansible](https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_cinder/blob/master/tasks/cinder_service_setup.yml)


**Environment**:
- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`): 1.7.3
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration**: OpenStack clouds
- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): fedora atomic
- Kernel (e.g. `uname -a`): latest
- Install tools: magnum
- Others:
